content.content: The absolute value or modulus of a real number x is its distance from 0 on the number line. We write the absolute value of x as |x|.
The modulus or absolute value of a real number is its size, ignoring its sign. We denote the modulus of x by |x|.

content.problem: If a = -7 and b = 3, find: a) |a + b|  b) |ab|

content.content: |x| is the distance of x from 0 on the number line. Because the modulus is a distance, it cannot be negative.
The absolute value of x is |x| = { x if x >= 0, -x if x < 0 }
The relation y = |x| is in fact a function. We call it the absolute value function.
content.graph_description: V-shaped graph with vertex at origin. Left branch: y = -x for x < 0. Right branch: y = x for x >= 0.

content.content: The absolute value of the function f(x) is |f(x)| = { f(x) if f(x) >= 0, -f(x) if f(x) < 0 }
method: Reflect the graph in the x-axis for f(x) < 0, discarding what was there
Points on the x-axis are unchanged

content.problem: Draw the graph of f(x) = 3x(x - 2) and on the same set of axes draw the graph of y = |f(x)|.
content.solution: The graph of y = f(x) is unchanged for f(x) >= 0 and reflected in the x-axis for f(x) < 0.

content.content: To find the points of intersection of the graphs of y = f(x) and y = g(x), we solve the equation f(x) = g(x). The solutions of this equation give us the x-coordinates of the intersection points. The y-coordinates can then be found by substituting the x-coordinates into one of the functions.

content.problem: Find the coordinates of the points of intersection of the graphs with equations y = x^2 - x + 3 and y = 2x + 7.

solution.step1: The graphs meet when x^2 - x + 3 = 2x + 7
solution.step5: Substituting into y = 2x + 7: when x = -1, y = 2(-1) + 7 = 5; when x = 4, y = 2(4) + 7 = 15
